items.text: I get excited when I see a new opportunity, even if it involves some risk.
items.rationale: Eagerness toward novel opportunities and willingness to accept risk are hallmarks of approach motivation.

items.text: When something interests me, I feel a strong pull to pursue it immediately.
items.rationale: Describes the appetitive drive and urgency characteristic of high approach motivation.

items.text: I am the kind of person who goes after what they want with full energy.
items.rationale: Behavioral self-description of goal-directed pursuit, a core feature of approach motivation.

items.text: The possibility of a reward motivates me more than the threat of a punishment.
items.rationale: Directly contrasts reward sensitivity (approach) with punishment sensitivity (avoidance), clearly favoring approach.

items.text: People who know me would say I'm always chasing the next big thing.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of persistent reward-seeking behavior, central to approach motivation.

items.text: I feel most alive when I'm actively working toward a goal I care about.
items.rationale: Positive affect linked to goal pursuit is a defining affective signature of approach motivation.

items.text: When I hear about a new challenge, my first instinct is to jump in.
items.rationale: Spontaneous engagement with challenges reflects strong behavioral activation.

items.text: I often act quickly to seize an opportunity before it passes.
items.rationale: Rapid action toward potential rewards reflects high approach-driven behavioral activation.

items.text: I find it easy to get enthusiastic about future plans and possibilities.
items.rationale: Anticipatory positive affect toward future rewards is a core component of approach motivation.

items.text: Winning or succeeding gives me an intense rush that keeps me pushing forward.
items.rationale: Strong positive reinforcement from success and its motivating effect are central to approach systems.

items.text: I tend to focus on what I can gain from a situation rather than what I might lose.
items.rationale: Gain-framing orientation is a cognitive hallmark distinguishing approach from avoidance motivation.

items.text: I have a hard time holding back when something exciting is within reach.
items.rationale: Difficulty inhibiting reward-directed behavior reflects strong behavioral activation system engagement.

items.text: I sometimes take on too many projects because everything seems appealing.
items.rationale: Overcommitment driven by appetitive interest suggests high approach motivation, though could also reflect poor planning or impulsivity.

items.text: I'm drawn to competitive situations where there's a clear winner.
items.rationale: Attraction to competition reflects reward sensitivity, but competitiveness could also stem from fear of losing (avoidance).

items.text: I set ambitious goals because I'm afraid of settling for a mediocre life.
items.rationale: Goal-setting appears approach-oriented, but the underlying fear of mediocrity introduces avoidance motivation as the driver.

items.text: I spend a lot of time thinking about what could go wrong before making a decision.
items.rationale: Anticipatory threat appraisal and rumination about negative outcomes are core cognitive features of avoidance motivation.

items.text: I would rather stick with what I know than risk trying something unfamiliar.
items.rationale: Preference for the familiar over the novel to minimize uncertainty is a behavioral hallmark of avoidance motivation.

items.text: My primary goal in most situations is to avoid making mistakes.
items.rationale: Error-avoidance as a primary motivational orientation directly reflects the behavioral inhibition system.

items.text: I feel more relief when I dodge a bad outcome than joy when something good happens.
items.rationale: Stronger affective response to threat removal than to reward attainment is a defining feature of avoidance-dominant motivation.

items.text: Others have told me I'm overly cautious and that I hold myself back.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of excessive caution and behavioral inhibition clearly maps to avoidance motivation.

items.text: When I imagine the future, I mostly think about threats and problems I need to prepare for.
items.rationale: Future-oriented threat focus reflects the vigilance and negativity bias characteristic of avoidance motivation.

items.text: I often turn down invitations or opportunities because I worry they won't go well.
items.rationale: Behavioral withdrawal from potential negative outcomes is a direct behavioral expression of avoidance motivation.

items.text: The fear of failure is usually a stronger motivator for me than the hope of success.
items.rationale: Explicitly contrasts punishment sensitivity with reward sensitivity, clearly endorsing avoidance-dominant motivation.

items.text: I tend to rehearse conversations in my head to make sure I don't say the wrong thing.
items.rationale: Preventive mental rehearsal aimed at avoiding social errors reflects behavioral inhibition and threat sensitivity.

items.text: I find it very difficult to relax when there's even a small chance something could go wrong.
items.rationale: Chronic vigilance and inability to disengage from threat monitoring are hallmarks of high avoidance motivation.

items.text: I prefer jobs with high security over jobs with high potential but uncertain outcomes.
items.rationale: Choosing security over potential gain reflects loss-aversion and uncertainty avoidance central to avoidance motivation.

items.text: When I succeed at something, my first thought is often about how I almost failed.
items.rationale: Reframing success through a threat lens indicates persistent activation of the behavioral inhibition system even after positive outcomes.

items.text: I double-check my work multiple times because I can't stand the idea of an error slipping through.
items.rationale: Repeated checking is driven by error avoidance, though it could also reflect conscientiousness or perfectionism independent of threat sensitivity.

items.text: I keep a low profile in group settings because I don't want to draw negative attention.
items.rationale: Social withdrawal to prevent negative evaluation reflects avoidance motivation, though it could partly reflect introversion or social anxiety as a trait.

items.text: I carefully plan every detail of a project so that nothing is left to chance.
items.rationale: Meticulous planning to eliminate uncertainty could reflect avoidance-driven threat minimization, but it also strongly resembles high approach motivation channeled through conscientious goal pursuit.
